results.title: My Brilliant Career paperback
results.brief_description: My Brilliant Career, adapted from Stella Miles Franklin’s 1901 novel of the same name, was Gillian Armstrong’s first feature film and a global success, gaining Academy Award and Palme d’Or nominations.

constellations_primary.name: Pen names, poems and puppets
constellations_primary.description: Discover how big-screen adaptations of novels connect to web-based poetry and Jim Henson's Fraggle Rock.

results.description: Paperback book ‘My Brilliant Career’, with soft cover and the title written on front in red ‘My Brilliant Career’, on a black background and in white text authors name ‘Miles Franklin’.

results.title: Loch Eck day/night dissolving magic lantern slides
results.brief_description: Day becomes night over Loch Eck in these dissolving magic lantern slides. Dissolves created transitions between scenes by superimposing matching projections and carefully dimming one slide while brightening the other.
results.description:
Day becomes night over Loch Eck in these dissolving magic lantern slides. Dissolves created transitions between scenes by superimposing matching projections and carefully dimming one slide while brightening the other. 

Other common dissolving effects included transforming black-and-white images into dazzling colour and conjuring heavenly or devilish figures into scenes to bewitch and beguile audiences. Like many techniques born from the visual language of magic lanterns, the dissolve effect was incorporated into filmmaking and is still used today.
description_for_label:
Day becomes night over Loch Eck in these dissolving magic lantern slides. Dissolves created transitions between scenes by superimposing matching projections and carefully dimming one slide while brightening the other. 

Other common dissolving effects included transforming black-and-white images into dazzling colour and conjuring heavenly or devilish figures into scenes to bewitch and beguile audiences. Like many techniques born from the visual language of magic lanterns, the dissolve effect was incorporated into filmmaking and is still used today.

results.title: Lady Sarah (Rachel Weisz) costume from The Favourite
results.credit_line:
Cotton, linen, wool, nylon, canvas, leather, spandex, brass, plastic, leather, rubber, felt, feathers, bamboo and rag paper, synthetic polyester fibre

Courtesy of The Walt Disney Company
results.material_description: cotton, linen, wool, nylon, canvas, leather, spandex, brass, lastic, leather, rubber, felt, feathers, bamboo and rag paper, synethetic polyester fiber
results.brief_description: As Queen Anne’s childhood friend and confidant, Sarah Churchill (Rachel Weisz) wields enormous influence in 18th-century England and her clothing in The Favourite (2018) symbolises her power.

constellations_primary.name: Powerful women in the frame and behind the scenes
constellations_primary.description: Lady Sarah (Rachel Weisz) exudes power in The Favourite. These female filmmakers and actors do too.

results.description:
In The Favourite (2018), the only thing sharper than Lady Sarah’s (Rachel Weisz) wit is her silhouette. As Queen Anne’s childhood friend and confidant, Sarah Churchill wields enormous influence in 18th-century England, and her clothing symbolises her power.

This jacket often features in scenes where Sarah exerts her command, particularly while shooting with her rival, Abigail (Emma Stone). Costume designer Sandy Powell made it in a similar shape to men’s shooting jackets – to demonstrate Sarah’s liberation from the gender politics of the time – yet kept a feminine touch. Sarah also wears breeches as she navigates (and controls) the male-dominated world of military strategy and domestic politics.
description_for_label:
In The Favourite (2018), the only thing sharper than Lady Sarah’s (Rachel Weisz) wit is her silhouette. As Queen Anne’s childhood friend and confidant, Sarah Churchill wields enormous influence in 18th-century England, and her clothing symbolises her power.

This jacket often features in scenes where Sarah exerts her command, particularly while shooting with her rival, Abigail (Emma Stone). Costume designer Sandy Powell made it in a similar shape to men’s shooting jackets – to demonstrate Sarah’s liberation from the gender politics of the time – yet kept a feminine touch. Sarah also wears breeches as she navigates (and controls) the male-dominated world of military strategy and domestic politics.

results.title: Abigail (Emma Stone) costume from The Favourite
results.credit_line:
Cotton, linen, nylon, canvas, pearl, ribbon, bamboo and rag paper, synthetic polyester fibre

Courtesy of the Walt Disney Company
results.material_description: Cotton, linen, nylon, canvas, pearl, ribbon, bamboo and rag paper, synethtic polyester fiber
results.brief_description: When we first meet Abigail Masham (Emma Stone) in The Favourite (2018), she’s covered in mud after being kicked from a carriage. It’s a humble start, but as she climbs Queen Anne’s (Olivia Colman) court her costumes become increasingly lavish.

constellations_primary.name: Making films in black and white
constellations_primary.description: Oscar-winner Sandy Powell crafted Abigail's (Emma Stone) costume in The Favourite to represent her ascension in the royal household of Queen Anne by utilising black and white.

results.description: Abigail Masham (Emma Stone) is down on her luck. Her wealthy family has made bad investments, and when we first meet her in The Favourite (2018), she’s pleading (politely) for a job in Queen Anne’s palace. It’s not the most flattering start – she’s covered in mud after being kicked from a carriage – but she’s soon promoted to lady-in-waiting and trades her grubby attire for a sleek black dress. As she climbs up the court, more and more white is added to her outfit, demonstrated by the trim on this costume. By the end of the film she’s draped in a completely over-the-top white dress that establishes her influence and shows how far she’s come.
description_for_label: Abigail Masham (Emma Stone) is down on her luck. Her wealthy family has made bad investments, and when we first meet her in The Favourite (2018), she’s pleading (politely) for a job in Queen Anne’s palace. It’s not the most flattering start – she’s covered in mud after being kicked from a carriage – but she’s soon promoted to lady-in-waiting and trades her grubby attire for a sleek black dress. As she climbs up the court, more and more white is added to her outfit, demonstrated by the trim on this costume. By the end of the film she’s draped in a completely over-the-top white dress that establishes her influence and shows how far she’s come.

results.title: Wentworth Correctional Centre ID Pass for Jake Stewart
results.brief_description: Wentworth’s impact on the local industry is just as important as its global popularity, providing countless opportunities for women on both sides of the camera. It also explores complex female-focused themes including institutionalised power, female transgression and violence, motherhood and LGBTQIA+ sexuality.
